summary: This is an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York to law enforcement colleagues, requesting detailed information on the whereabouts and surveillance of Ghislaine Maxwell in April 2020. It also inquires about the status of evidence review, including search warrant returns and outstanding FBI interview reports (302s).

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The email is focused on locating her, her potential phone usage, and her residence, indicating she is a central target of the investigation.

persons.name: Flatley
persons.context: Mentioned as the source of information that AUSAs do not have search warrant return materials due to technical issues, but other teams should have access.

connections.description: The AUSA is actively seeking information to locate and build a case against Maxwell.

events.title: Email Request for Maxwell Location and Evidence Status
events.description: An AUSA sends a detailed email requesting the latest information on Ghislaine Maxwell's whereabouts, surveillance efforts, phone usage, and the status of evidence review and FBI interview reports.

events.title: Pen Register on Maxwell's Phone
events.description: A pen register (call detail record collection) was active on a phone number associated with Maxwell's entity, the Terramar Project, from approximately October 2019 through mid-March 2020.

keyFacts: In April 2020, prosecutors were actively seeking to locate Ghislaine Maxwell, with a belief she might be residing at a boyfriend's residence in Massachusetts.
Investigators were tracking a phone number (917-520-3106) registered to Maxwell's entity, the 'Terramar Project,' to confirm if she was personally using it.
A pen register on the suspected phone number had expired about a month prior to the email, and prosecutors inquired about reactivating it.
Prosecutors noted they had not yet received approximately 41 FBI interview reports (302s), including one from an interview conducted about two months prior, hindering their review.
Technical problems with exporting data to the 'Relativity' review platform were preventing AUSAs from accessing search warrant return materials directly.
